text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English 
with Jennifer. You may think that by now

I've covered every grammar topic possible. 
I've been online for more than 10 years,

but there's always something more to teach, 
something more to learn. I have yet to cover

modals of certainty in the present and future. 
Hopefully, I'll do that sooner rather than later.

Look at the structure I just used. I have yet 
to cover modals of certainty. Have yet to cover.

What does that mean? In this lesson, we'll talk 
about "have yet to do" and "have yet to be done."

A negative verb in the present perfect 
allows us to express what we expect to do,

but haven't done yet. I haven't made 
a video on modals of certainty yet.
I haven't taught that grammar point yet.
We haven't studied that together yet.

Okay. These sentences are what I'd say 
in everyday English. I can restate these

ideas using infinitives, and I'm also going to 
change the position of the adverb "yet." Watch.
I have yet to make a video on modals of certainty.
I have yet to teach that grammar point.

Do you see the pattern? First of 
all, I don't use any contractions.

This is formal English, and I use "yet" 
immediately after the helping verb.
Try this last one on your own.
We have yet to study that together.

Get it? We can also use this 
pattern with passive verbs.
It works well in official announcements. Look.
The next topic hasn't been decided yet.

I'm going to change that to: The 
next topic has yet to be decided.

Again, I avoid contractions. "Yet" follows 
the helping verb. The passive infinitive
is "to be" + the past participle.
Can you change these sentences?
The filming location has yet to be determined.
Videos on essay writing have yet to be made.

You can have fun with this structure. It's 
formal and perfect for moments of inspiration.

I have yet to conquer this 
mountain, but one day I will.

What do you think this person is 
saying? Tell me in the comments.

Before we end, I'll share one variation 
with the verb "be." The best is yet to come.

In this sentence, it's not about doing something 
or making something happen. It's more about

waiting for it to happen or anticipating that 
it will happen one day. The best is yet to come.

What do you think? Is the best yet to come? 
Here's a practice task full of optimism.

Rewrite the sentences using "have yet 
to." Put your answers in the comments.

That's all for now. Please like 
the video if you found it useful.
As always, thanks for watching and happy studies!

Follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and 
Instagram. Why not join me on Patreon?
And don't forget to subscribe on YouTube.
